repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Quality and affordable health
            care for all

abstracts.cdata!:
The heath system modernization (HSM)
            project has helped Armenia’s most vulnerable citizens
            increase their geographical and financial access to quality
            basic health services, through infrastructure development,
            more modern equipment in rural health facilities, and
            enhanced knowledge and skills among primary health care
            (PHC) providers. Roughly 89 percent of the people are now
            covered by retrained family medical providers compared to 47
            percent in 2006. Moreover, improving the quality of the
            principal regional hospitals and health care providers and
            developing the PHC infrastructure in rural areas will
            eventually reorient regional patient flows from the capital
            Yerevan to local health facilities. The recently approved
            additional financing (AF) supports a further transition to
            family medicine-based PHC, the completion of the regional
            hospital modernization process, and the institutional
            strengthening of the overall system.

docna.cdata!:
Armenia - Quality and affordable health care
            for all

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Quality and affordable
            health care for all

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Laying the foundations for
            sustainable development

abstracts.cdata!:
Armenia's economy has undergone a
            profound transformation since independence in the early
            1990s. Today, it is market oriented and highly receptive to
            trade, capital, and technological innovation. From the late
            1990s to 2008, gross domestic product (GDP) expanded by
            double digits on average, and Armenia now ranks as a lower
            middle-income country. As a result of sustained growth,
            ambitious reforms, and external inflows of capital and
            remittances, poverty plunged from over 55 percent at the
            start of the transition to less than 36 percent in 2010.

Armenia - Laying the foundations for
            sustainable development

abstracts.cdata!:
To update her medical skills, Doctor
            Teresa Petrosyan travels 16 kilometers to Argavand village
            to attend hands-on classes in family medicine. Her teacher
            is certified family physician Dr. Lena Gevorgyan, who is
            happy to share her experience. She says that in her time,
            she, too, was well trained by others. Dr. Gevorgyan has been
            working with doctors in regional Armenia to refresh their
            knowledge of family medicine and teach them new techniques
            and new ways of interacting with patients. It's like a
            master's degree course where family doctors learn how
            to best handle a wide variety of medical challenges, most
            likely alone in a walk-in clinic. In Armenia, 800,000
            patients have been treated in 145 improved outpatient
            clinics. However, 70 outpatient units around the country
            still need to be moved to new buildings.

            OPTIMIZATION PROJECT,TF053436-PHRD-ARMENIA: HEALTH SYSTEMS
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health System
            Modernization Project for Armenia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: institutionalization of important
            activities such as National Health Accounts (NHAs) and
            Health Sector Performance Assessment (HSPAs) can be achieved
            with strong commitment from relevant staff and management
            who understand the benefits for decision making derived from
            the reports. The program has been able to achieve success
            because reforms spanned key areas of the health care system.
            The health strategy in Armenia gives evidence of a balanced
            choice between visible results in terms of
            rehabilitation/construction and service delivery on the one
            side and the development of a policy framework and
            medium-term planning on the other side.

13881703.trustfund:
TF026804-PHRD-ARMENIA: HEALTH SYSTEM
            OPTIMIZATION PROJECT,TF053436-PHRD-ARMENIA: HEALTH SYSTEMS
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            modernizing health care in Armenia. During the last two
            decades, Armenia faced enormous economic difficulties and
            crisis in social spheres, including the health care system.
            The main challenge in Armenia’s health system was to ensure
            better access of the population to quality health services.
            The Health System Modernization (HSM) Project was designed
            to improve the organization of the country’s health care
            system so as to provide more accessible, quality and
            sustainable health care services to the population. The HSM
            Project has helped increase the geographical and financial
            access of Armenia’s most vulnerable population to quality
            basic health services through infrastructure development,
            provision of modern equipment to health facilities in rural
            areas, and the upgrading of Primary Health Care (PHC)
            service providers’ knowledge and skills. About 80 percent of
            the country’s population was covered by retrained family
            medicine providers. Turning the principal hospital networks
            in the country’s regions into a high quality health care
            provider’s network, accompanied by a development of the PHC
            infrastructure in rural areas, reoriented regional patient
            flows from the capital city of Yerevan to the local health facilities.

            OPTIMIZATION PROJECT,TF053436-PHRD-ARMENIA: HEALTH SYSTEMS
            MODERNIZATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            modernizing health care in Armenia. During the last two
            decades, Armenia faced enormous economic difficulties and
            crisis in social spheres, including the health care system.
            The main challenge in Armenia’s health system was to ensure
            better access of the population to quality health services.
            The Health System Modernization (HSM) Project was designed
            to improve the organization of the country’s health care
            system so as to provide more accessible, quality and
            sustainable health care services to the population. The HSM
            Project has helped increase the geographical and financial
            access of Armenia’s most vulnerable population to quality
            basic health services through infrastructure development,
            provision of modern equipment to health facilities in rural
            areas, and the upgrading of Primary Health Care (PHC)
            service providers’ knowledge and skills. About 80 percent of
            the country’s population was covered by retrained family
            medicine providers. Turning the principal hospital networks
            in the country’s regions into a high quality health care
            provider’s network, accompanied by a development of the PHC
            infrastructure in rural areas, reoriented regional patient
            flows from the capital city of Yerevan to the local health facilities.

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Health System Modernization
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Health System
            Modernization Project for Armenia is to improve the
            organization of the health care system in order to provide
            more accessible, quality and sustainable health care
            services to the population, in particular to the most
            vulnerable groups; and better manage public health threats.
            The reallocation is necessary to support the ongoing project
            activities which were revised in 2008-2009 as well as to
            fulfill contract obligations signed through tenders. In
            2006, agreement was reached between the Government and the
            Bank to include in the project the renovation of Ijevan and
            Hrazdan Medical centers; and to carry out the renovation,
            two civil works contracts totaling US$2,577,500 were signed.
            The second health system performance assessment and the 2008
            national health accounts reports have been published.
            However, no further progress has been observed in the
            implementation of activities on improving governance
            arrangements of public hospitals. Similarly, no progress has
            been made in the independent audit of hospitals in 2009, as
            the allocation of funds to the public hospitals to conduct
            audit was not considered by the Government due to lack of
            state budget in view of the economic crisis. The Government
            has now planned to allocate resources for hospital
            independent audit in the 2011 health budget with the
            expectations that the state budget will come out from the
            effect of deep recession. The project will close on June 30,
            2010. The next mission is planned for May 2010. The
            implementation completion report (ICR) will be prepared in
            September 2010.
